segment.source: Understanding Servicing Strategies
segment.target: Understanding Servicing Strategies

segment.source: Understanding Servicing Strategies
segment.target: Understanding Servicing Strategies

segment.source: Understanding Servicing Strategies
segment.target: Understanding Servicing Strategies

segment.source: A Windows® image can be serviced at various phases of deployment in the following ways: offline, during an automated installation, or online.
segment.target: A Windows® image can be serviced at various phases of deployment in the following ways: offline, during an automated installation, or online.

segment.source: The phase of deployment that you select depends on your deployment strategy.
segment.target: The phase of deployment that you select depends on your deployment strategy.

segment.source: Offline Servicing: Involves adding and removing updates, drivers, and language packs, and configuring other settings, without booting Windows.
segment.target: Offline Servicing: Involves adding and removing updates, drivers, and language packs, and configuring other settings, without booting Windows.

segment.source: Offline servicing is an efficient way to manage existing images that are stored on a server because it eliminates the need for re-creating updated images.
segment.target: Offline servicing is an efficient way to manage existing images that are stored on a server because it eliminates the need for re-creating updated images.

segment.source: You can perform offline servicing on an image that is mounted or applied to a drive or directory.
segment.target: You can perform offline servicing on an image that is mounted or applied to a drive or directory.

segment.source: Servicing an Image by Using Windows Setup: Involves providing an answer file (Unattend.xml) that Windows Setup implements.
segment.target: Servicing an Image by Using Windows Setup: Involves providing an answer file (Unattend.xml) that Windows Setup implements.

segment.source: The answer file contains specific servicing operations such as adding drivers, updates, language packs, and other packages.
segment.target: The answer file contains specific servicing operations such as adding drivers, updates, language packs, and other packages.

segment.source: Servicing an image during an automated installation can be easily implemented and is ideal for Setup-based deployment.
segment.target: Servicing an image during an automated installation can be easily implemented and is ideal for Setup-based deployment.

segment.source: Servicing a Running Operating System: Also known as online servicing, this method involves booting to audit mode to add drivers, applications, and other packages.
segment.target: Servicing a Running Operating System: Also known as online servicing, this method involves booting to audit mode to add drivers, applications, and other packages.

segment.source: Online servicing is ideal for drivers when the driver packages have co-installers or application dependencies.
segment.target: Online servicing is ideal for drivers when the driver packages have co-installers or application dependencies.

segment.source: It is also efficient when most of your servicing packages have installers, or the updates are in .msi or KB.exe file formats, or the applications rely on Windows installed services and technologies (such as the .NET Framework or full Plug and Play support).
segment.target: It is also efficient when most of your servicing packages have installers, or the updates are in .msi or KB.exe file formats, or the applications rely on Windows installed services and technologies (such as the .NET Framework or full Plug and Play support).

segment.source: The following illustration shows the servicing opportunities available during the various phases of deployment.
segment.target: The following illustration shows the servicing opportunities available during the various phases of deployment.

segment.source: windows servicing strategies
segment.target: windows servicing strategies

segment.source: Offline Servicing
segment.target: Offline Servicing

segment.source: Offline servicing was introduced with Windows Vista.
segment.target: Offline servicing was introduced with Windows Vista.

segment.source: Offline servicing occurs when you modify or service a Windows image entirely offline without booting it first.
segment.target: Offline servicing occurs when you modify or service a Windows image entirely offline without booting it first.

segment.source: For Windows Vista, the Package Manager command-line tool was provided for updating Windows images.
segment.target: For Windows Vista, the Package Manager command-line tool was provided for updating Windows images.

segment.source: In Windows 7 and Windows 8, Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) replaces Package Manager.
segment.target: In Windows 7 and Windows 8, Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) replaces Package Manager.

segment.source: For Windows 8, most operating system servicing operations can be performed on an offline Windows image by using the DISM command-line tool.
segment.target: For Windows 8, most operating system servicing operations can be performed on an offline Windows image by using the DISM command-line tool.

segment.source: DISM is installed with Windows 8, and also distributed in the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK).
segment.target: DISM is installed with Windows 8, and also distributed in the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (Windows ADK).

segment.source: For more information about DISM, see DISM - Deployment Image Servicing and Management Technical Reference for Windows.
segment.target: For more information about DISM, see DISM - Deployment Image Servicing and Management Technical Reference for Windows.

segment.source: DISM can be used on an offline image to:
segment.target: DISM can be used on an offline image to:

segment.source: Mount, remount, and unmount an image in a .wim file for servicing.
segment.target: Mount, remount, and unmount an image in a .wim file for servicing.

segment.source: Query information about a Windows image.
segment.target: Query information about a Windows image.

segment.source: Add, remove, and enumerate drivers provided as .inf files.
segment.target: Add, remove, and enumerate drivers provided as .inf files.

segment.source: Add, remove, and enumerate packages, including language packs, provided as .cab files.
segment.target: Add, remove, and enumerate packages, including language packs, provided as .cab files.

segment.source: Add .msu files.
segment.target: Add .msu files.

segment.source: Configure international settings.
segment.target: Configure international settings.

segment.source: Enable, disable, and enumerate Windows operating system features.
segment.target: Enable, disable, and enumerate Windows operating system features.

segment.source: Upgrade to a higher edition of Windows.
segment.target: Upgrade to a higher edition of Windows.

segment.source: Check the applicability of a Windows Installer application patch (.msp file).
segment.target: Check the applicability of a Windows Installer application patch (.msp file).

segment.source: Enumerate applications and application patches installed in a Windows image.
segment.target: Enumerate applications and application patches installed in a Windows image.

segment.source: Apply the offline servicing section of an unattended answer file.
segment.target: Apply the offline servicing section of an unattended answer file.

segment.source: Update a Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) image.
segment.target: Update a Windows Preinstallation Environment (Windows PE) image.

segment.source: For more information about how to service a mounted image, see Service a Mounted Windows Image.
segment.target: For more information about how to service a mounted image, see Service a Mounted Windows Image.

segment.source: For more information about how to service an applied image, see Service an Applied Windows Image.
segment.target: For more information about how to service an applied image, see Service an Applied Windows Image.

segment.source: Servicing an Image by Using Windows Setup
segment.target: Servicing an Image by Using Windows Setup

segment.source: Use an unattended answer file with Windows Setup to service an image during the various configuration passes of Windows Setup.
segment.target: Use an unattended answer file with Windows Setup to service an image during the various configuration passes of Windows Setup.

segment.source: The answer file contains all the settings that are used to configure and update the Windows image.
segment.target: The answer file contains all the settings that are used to configure and update the Windows image.

segment.source: Setup calls the answer file multiple times during the deployment process.
segment.target: Setup calls the answer file multiple times during the deployment process.

segment.source: After the operating system is installed, you can boot to audit mode or Windows Welcome.
segment.target: After the operating system is installed, you can boot to audit mode or Windows Welcome.

segment.source: For more information about Windows Setup, see Windows Setup Technical Reference.
segment.target: For more information about Windows Setup, see Windows Setup Technical Reference.

segment.source: For more information about configuration passes, see Windows Setup Configuration Passes.
segment.target: For more information about configuration passes, see Windows Setup Configuration Passes.

segment.source: An unattended answer file can be used during setup to:
segment.target: An unattended answer file can be used during setup to:

segment.source: Add or remove a language pack.
segment.target: Add or remove a language pack.

segment.source: Configure international settings.
segment.target: Configure international settings.

segment.source: Add and remove drivers.
segment.target: Add and remove drivers.

segment.source: Add and remove packages.
segment.target: Add and remove packages.

segment.source: Enable and disable Windows operating system features.
segment.target: Enable and disable Windows operating system features.

segment.source: Servicing a Running Operating System
segment.target: Servicing a Running Operating System

segment.source: There are several tools that can be used to service a running operating system (also known as servicing an online image).
segment.target: There are several tools that can be used to service a running operating system (also known as servicing an online image).

segment.source: You should boot to audit mode to add updates to your Windows image.
segment.target: You should boot to audit mode to add updates to your Windows image.

segment.source: Audit mode does not require settings in Windows Welcome to be applied, allowing quicker access to the desktop.
segment.target: Audit mode does not require settings in Windows Welcome to be applied, allowing quicker access to the desktop.

segment.source: After you have booted to audit mode, you can add Plug and Play device drivers, install applications and system components, and test the validity of the installation.
segment.target: After you have booted to audit mode, you can add Plug and Play device drivers, install applications and system components, and test the validity of the installation.

segment.source: For more information about how to use audit mode, see Boot Windows to Audit Mode or OOBE.
segment.target: For more information about how to use audit mode, see Boot Windows to Audit Mode or OOBE.

segment.source: The following tools are typically used to update a running Windows operating system:
segment.target: The following tools are typically used to update a running Windows operating system:

segment.source: Use DISM to enumerate drivers, international settings, packages, and features, and to apply unattended answer file settings.
segment.target: Use DISM to enumerate drivers, international settings, packages, and features, and to apply unattended answer file settings.

segment.source: For more information, see DISM - Deployment Image Servicing and Management Technical Reference for Windows.
segment.target: For more information, see DISM - Deployment Image Servicing and Management Technical Reference for Windows.

segment.source: Use DPInst to add drivers for detected hardware.
segment.target: Use DPInst to add drivers for detected hardware.

segment.source: For information about DPInst and other tools available in the Windows Driver Kit (WDK), see Download kits and tools for Windows.
segment.target: For information about DPInst and other tools available in the Windows Driver Kit (WDK), see Download kits and tools for Windows.

segment.source: Use PNPUtil to add, remove, and enumerate drivers.
segment.target: Use PNPUtil to add, remove, and enumerate drivers.

segment.source: For more information, see Use PnPUtil at a command line to install a Plug and Play device.
segment.target: For more information, see Use PnPUtil at a command line to install a Plug and Play device.

segment.source: Use Windows Update Stand-Alone Installer to add service packs or other .msu files.
segment.target: Use Windows Update Stand-Alone Installer to add service packs or other .msu files.

segment.source: For more information, see Description of the Windows Update Stand-alone Installer (Wusa.exe) and of .msu Files in Windows Vista
segment.target: For more information, see Description of the Windows Update Stand-alone Installer (Wusa.exe) and of .msu Files in Windows Vista

segment.source: Use LPKSetup to add or remove language packs.
segment.target: Use LPKSetup to add or remove language packs.
